content.user_title: Create clear and maintainable git commits
content.value_statement: This skill helps developers write better commit messages and structure commits effectively. It provides guidelines for creating a clean, searchable commit history that teams can understand and navigate.
actual_capabilities: Guides developers on making small and focused commits
Teaches how to break big changes into logical commits
Encourages running linter and formatting before committing
limitations: Does not execute git commands automatically
Does not integrate with git hosting platforms

use_cases.title: Improve personal commit habits
use_cases.description: Learn to write clear commit messages that help you track changes over time

use_cases.title: Establish team commit standards
use_cases.description: Guide team members to create consistent and searchable commit histories

use_cases.title: Follow project guidelines
use_cases.description: Contribute clean commits that project maintainers can review easily

prompt_templates.title: Basic commit help
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need guidance on making commits
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a good commit for this change: [describe your change]

prompt_templates.title: Review commit message
prompt_templates.scenario: When you want to improve a commit message
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my commit message and suggest improvements: [paste your commit message]

prompt_templates.title: Split large changes
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have a big change to commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me break down this large change into logical commits: [describe the change]

prompt_templates.title: Team standards
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a commit message guide for my team working on [project type]

output_examples.input: Help me create a good commit for adding user authentication
output: Focus on the single change of adding user authentication
Run your linter and formatter first
Write a clear subject line describing the change
Add context in the body if the commit is complex

output_examples.input: Help me break down my large refactoring into logical commits
output: Identify the separate concerns in your refactoring
Create one commit per concern (e.g., API changes, UI updates, tests)
Ensure each commit builds successfully on its own
Write descriptive messages for each commit type

output_examples.input: Review my commit message for a bug fix
output: Your message clearly describes the what but not the why
Add context about the bug this fix addresses
Consider referencing the issue number if applicable
Keep the subject line under 50 characters

best_practices: Make commits small and focused on one concern
Run linter and formatter before every commit
Write descriptive commit messages that explain why the change was needed
anti_patterns: Creating huge commits with unrelated changes
Committing without running code quality tools
Using vague messages like 'fix' or 'update' without details

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for git commit guidance.

faq.question: What is the recommended commit size?
faq.answer: Keep commits focused on a single concern. Small commits are easier to review and revert.

faq.question: How does this integrate with my workflow?
faq.answer: Ask for commit guidance when preparing changes. The skill provides recommendations for messages and structure.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides guidance. It does not access files or execute git commands.

faq.question: Why should I run linter before committing?
faq.answer: Running linter and formatter ensures consistent code style and catches issues before they enter the commit history.

faq.question: How is this different from commit message tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides guidelines and advice rather than generating commit messages automatically.
